Before playing this game, I've heard and knew a bit about Slender Man and other related stuff, but not much. So that said, I was curious to give this game a go, especially since I love horror games and giving myself a good scare once in awhile. Let's just say that this game did not disappoint. Although it was a bit of a short game as I clocked in around 2.5 hours, completing it in two sessions, I've got no regrets about purchasing or playing the game. It was a good experience I enjoyed, which is what matters. And if I must say so, I was quite a fan of the soundtrack for this game, which I also purchased as well. I find it goes well with the game itself and definitely adds in that scare factor. It can also be creepy as well. I was impressed with the graphics. And controller support was a nice bonus too, as I was initially unsure if this game had it or not. And finally, I think this game has a pretty good story as well, which is an important thing I look for when I play video games. This game definitely has my curiosity of Slender Man intrigued now as I'm pretty sure I'm going to be looking more into this Slender Man stuff more. All in all, I enjoyed this game and I'd recommend it, especially if you want a good scare. And keeping in mind, I played the entire game in a pitch dark room with headphones.

*Note: this review was written before the 2.0 update and many issues have now been fixed*  This is one of those odd games to review. You see initially i was having an enjoyable experience and wondering why this game got lower scores but now that i look back i see some of the outstanding issues. At the beginning of the game I was pretty freaked out, you know, taking my time looking around every dark corner. This was good, the opening prologue level was probably my favourite part of the experience. But after the end of this level that's when things start to fall down. Slowly as you progress through each level the fear factor actually decreases. With brighter lit enviroments as you progress the game it took away some of the worry that i had since i no longer needed to worry about what was in the dark.(BTW i love darkness in games but when you make it so dark it's impossible to navigate i have an issue) Not only does the scare factor drop with the lighting system but when i first watched the Chaser from a distance i was more laughing than scared since the animation was jerky and the AI seemed to be in a state of pants-on-head ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥. This strikes me as odd though that an enemy that you will spend a lot of time looking at has crap animation while the Slenderman(the creature you'll want to spend the least time looking at) has proper and well designed animations. The other creature, Charlie, seemed to have near-non existant animations and when he was sitting still it looked more like a something from Doom where it's a 2D images worked into a 3D enviroment. The sound design feels well done with creature and enviroment noises adding to your already tense state. But i stopped for a minute when I heard the sounds from Slender: The Eight Pages. I guess it's supposed to be a callout to the last game but this is a new game and i'd like to hear improved versions of these sounds. Speaking of the last game, I did enjoy the Eight Pages remake level, which did a good job of calling out to the last game while still keeping a sense of originality. Now here's the big one besides the ending, the glitches. Now I only had one real gamebreaking bug but in horror games even if a bug isn't game breaking it can still absolutely ruin the immersion for a player. For example, the first time I played the Eight Pages level I had 7 pages and was freaking out ,worrying about the Slenderman but then I saw him and was baffled when he was about to kill me and then just left. I didn't see him like a ♥♥♥♥♥♥ and walked right into him and ♥♥♥♥ all happened. And I know this isn't supposed to happen since I tested the level other times. Other Slendy bugs were dying from him even though he was nowhere to be seen, him teleporting inside other objects and a weird one where he hovered above the ground. My gamebreaking bug was when I was caught by the Chaser and waited to die but the camera just sat there fixated on the Chaser's face like it had grabbed me. After a few minutes the Chaser started running away with the camera following it's face from the front. This continued for about 7 minutes before i gave up and had to restart the level. We now come to the ending. Now I feel like I could spoil the ending here and not ruin it for you at all but I won't for the sake of fanboys everywhere. What you should know is the ending is a major cliffhanger with nothing being resolved. It just kinda ends. Maybe I could have overlooked this but with the game being obnoxiously short it makes it un-compensatable. It feels like after the ending was actually once a level just a leading to the next level and they were just like, '♥♥♥♥ it we can sell it like this' and then just folded in.  So all in all, PROS: -Nicely designed enviroments -Atmospheric SFX and music -Very well directed opening -Small enclosed enviroments(buildings, etc...) -Scary and well designed creatures -Interesting secret level -Some genuinly scary moments  CONS: -Embarrasingly short -Buggy creature animation -Poor AI -Massively well lit sections -Repetitive objectives -Too much audio taken from S:EP -Many glitches and bugs -The door opening mechanics -Extremely aggravating to get the secret level -Unsatisfying ending  I wish there was a maybe button on Steam because that would suit this perfectly since there are good sequences but it is overall lacking so I'm afraid I can't recommend this unless it's on a decent sale.

Overall, its a pretty awesome game and I hope to see more from the devs.

Slender the Arrival is a decent game for its price. You're sure to have a few jumpscares, and a bit of a challenge on hardcore mode. The game has an interesting storyline for you to unravel, but it isn't forced upon you to do so. A few drawbacks are of how short the game is, and I personally didn't find it as scary as the original Slender. Also, it just didn't seem as intense as the original. You learn your surroundings quickly, losing the feeling of being lost... which is key for a Slender game. However, for the restricted time the developers had to create this game, I say it is respectable enough of a game to purchase.  Rating: 6.7 out of 10 by my perspective.

A horrible copypaste galore of jumpscares and random ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t.  The prologue of this game is actually the scariest part, seeing that you don't know what to expect if you haven't played it before. This is not scary, this is not thought out gameplay. I had hopes that the game would turn into something with more and better gameplay after the 8 pages part, but it's the exact same formula repeated yet again. Except find the stated number of the new type of item while avoiding slender and yet another extra monster at the same time.  It's not funny, it's not scary and it's just a randomized game of tag where you are chased by a no-clipping hacker with teleport. Stay away from this unless you really like jumpscares and copypaste gameplay.

VERSION 2.0 Review:  Slender The Arrival has certainly had shifts in quality between updates, and I am pleased to say that v2.0 is literally perfect. First off, the new levels are TERRIFYING. And I mean Amnesia terrifying, Homestead and Memories (the two new levels) are very memorable and are a great addition to the game. The Arrival looked amazing upon release, and yet v2.0 makes it look even better. There are better textures and models in some areas, and Genesis now looks fantastic rather than being a carbon copy of The Eight Pages with some of The Arrival's entities. The biggest flaw to S:TA before v2.0 was the gameplay; it was ridden by bugs and problems such as the overly frustrating mine level, terrible interaction physics, and the simply god awful fire sequence. Everything has been fixed in 2.0. The interaction is now smooth and comfortable, the mine level's main NPC (the source of the frustration) has been perfected, and the fire sequence is now an intense but fair climax.   Some gamers may be turned off by the ten dollar price tag for a 3 hour game, but guys, come on. A group of inexperienced indie developers worked their asses off for this and they deserve the money. Not to mention, this is one of the horror greats in gaming - I liked it almost as much as the Amnesia games. This is also the first game by Blue Isle Studios, and for an indie game group's first game this is amazing.   Overall it's an amazing game with a great story. Give it a go.

Slender the Arrival does it's best to give you a creepy experience but it just keeps falling flat. It is a very nonintuitive game. It's standard first person shooter controls (without the shooter) and places you in the creepy woods of a park. One of its main shortcomings is that it lacks the ability to deliver the story properly. We are supposed to make assumptions about everything. Assumptions that are probably wrong. I kept finding clues about a person and assumed that person might be me. Then it took reading some backstory in a walkthru to discover that I was a completely different person baguely mentioned in one of the notes. The first few times I played it I was throughly creeped out and some of the presentation helped with that. It uses a method of 'steady-cam' view that looks like you are filming this which can also be viewed that you are someone else watching this person's footage (a la Blair Witch Project, CLoverfield, or Paranormal Activity). What you find does heighten the tension and when odd things are seen it really creeps you out. But then it feels like a grind. Where am I supposed to go next you ask. Oh over there. Wait I think I've found everything. Do I go back? Where to next? There is a decisivve lack of direction and instruction. It gave me a goal but the goal was so vague that I didn't know whether I was finished nor did I know if I was finding the right things. I wandered around doing nothing SLOWLY for a half hour and then quit the game. Why? HEre is the biggeswt problem. There is no save feature. It saves once you finish 'THE CHAPTER'. I was stuck in the 'prologue' for days. Every time I tried it I had to start from the beginning. So by the 15th time I tried finding all the clues or whatever I was not afraid of the woods nor the creepy things. So far all I've seen are creepy things but none of them are harmful things. Don't get me wrong. This game has figured out that in horror you can't just in-your-face all the horror like Dead Space or Doom 3 etc. But it has to be subtle. But it hasn't fuguyred out pacing, story, furthering the adventure. It also relies a lot on camera glitches and sound effects and music. THose things are very important in horror. But in this case I am never sure if these elements actually appear in the game world or just in the game 'providing atmosphere' like I'm being followed around by a 40s radio SFX guy banging pots together and breathing heavily. It reminds me of the scares in the movie The Ring where Ehren Krueger hit us over the head with loud noises and in your face weird cut in pictures to scare us and when you got to the end all you could say was 'Huh?' I would be interested if this studio tried it again with horror as this was an improvement over its predecessor but it still isn't there. The controls and gameplay are still lacking. Your RUNNING mode isn't much faster than your WALKING mode. You can neither jump nor go in water so you feel like a child in one of those wheelie guides. The story needs a bit of polish. There needs to be a definite indication who I am and what I'm doing and how far I've gotten with it. Because leaving it up to my imagination is unacceptable in a game. How am _I_ supposed to know when I am done with a chapter if I don't know what I'm supposed to be looking for, etc. This will keep you entertained for a couple playthroughs until you give up and look through the readthroughs. (which don't really help as the items keep moving around) You want to get really scared, go for Five Nights at Freddy's.

Slender: The Arrival is a horror game based on the popular (and free) Slender: The Eight Pages. The game is relatively short (should be less than 2 hours for most people), and divided into several different chapters that each feature different gameplay. Fans of the original will notice a substantial visual improvement, and effective use of sound. This game understands how to execute a horror experience- make the protagonist defenseless, and build up tension before a single encounter.  The longest chapter is a recreation of the original Slender gameplay of collecting 8 pages, with them and their corresponding landmarks randomly distributed, with each further discovery angering a hostile presence in the woods. Simple enough, and it's absolutely chilling. Collecting the pages is reasonably guided inside a large area, but still confusing at first.  The sound and dim lighting crete a constant sense of unease, and when -something- appears, it caused a feeling of dread deep in my gut. Even knowing that it was silly to be surprised multiple times, I'd still jump. Twisted tree branches seen outside my flashlight often seemed like gnarled arms reaching out to me. There's something about games like this, and the Amnesia or Penumbra series, that strike at something deep and primal in the subconscious.   Every chapter after the first and second was not as impressive, and only one of them stood out to me. For gamers concerned about value for their dollar, this may be an issue. The story, told mostly through found letters, is pretty incomprehensible, and although good horror never shows all its cards, there's not a lot to grab hold of here.  Personally, though, I think the quality and intensity of the experience is worth the low asking price. A solid recommendation.

Created by the same team behind the originial, experimental, slender: the eight pages game, Slender: the arrival is a full, nerve shredding experience, which may as well have a reward for depriving me of sleep. Both from playing, and also from not being able to sleep afterwards.  While it is a very short game, there is plenty to find, after hours of playing around I still have not got all the notes. There may even be secret areas I am unaware of.  Since it's arrival on steam there has been new content, which fills in some loose gaps in gameplay, while adding to the experience.   It has a great atmosphere, nice graphics, is really scary and has a decent story.   The one problem; it could explain more. I get that it's trying to create a sense of mystery, and it's up to you to find out the lore behind the game through fidning notes lyting around, but it could at least explain your charecters role and their backstory more immediately, we are playing AS them, so why not know what they do?!  Other than shortness and a few optimisation issues, it's a great game, and seeing as it's the first commercial release by it's creators, it's a great effort!  If you love horror, go for it!

The campaign contains a lot of various 'missions', like finding eight pages, but in different environments with different encounters. A huge part of the game is also the story and exploration. I asume you already know the stories about Slender or just the main idea behind Slender, but in The Arrival it's a new story. You will find yourself searching for notes -not just to get further in the game, but also because you want to know the new story in this game.  All in all: This is my favorite horror game of all time. The atmosphere, the story, the graphics are all amazing and the special effects and sounds are superb. Great game, amazing atmosphere, deep storyline that needs alot of research to be completed. Alost 100 hours put into the game I still have things to explore and test, from map glitching to eastereggs, things to do remains abundant with the occasional and brutal scare. The only downside is the missed opportunity. With the amount of work put into the game, and the crazy development cycle, the main game is just too short. Perhaps it could be better if, considering how Lauren calls the shots but the path she takes is inevitable, the game wasn't so damn linear. The outcome of Lauren should change based oon the decisions you make and the paths you take. I congratulate you, however on the inspiration to start game development of my own (mainly because I'm pursuing the things the game could have done better).  8/10
